title: How to be a Drilling Data Analyst

content.body: DDA Job
Role Description

The Drilling Data Analyst role provides front line tech support to users, ensures that Corva is functioning as expected, ensures Corva is prepared for the next rig operation, and enters data required for the Corva apps to output useful/accurate information.

Front line tech support is primarily, but not exclusively, provided through the Intercom app and is the DDA’s number 1 priority. This is a client facing function and is considered important and time sensitive. The DDA should be familiar enough with the Corva apps that they can provide basic tech support on how to setup and use the apps. The DDA should also be able to identify abnormal behavior and perform basic remedial actions before escalating issues to support staff.

For Corva to function it needs to be connected to a data source. Most of the time the data source will be a WITSML stream. The DDA is responsible for connecting well assets in Corva to the corresponding WITSML stream in a timely manner. The DDA will use the WITSML service provider’s EDRs (if available) and/or PDS WITSML studio Desktop to determine if a WITSML stream is ready to be connected to an asset in Corva. Once the well is connected the DDA is responsible for verifying data is coming in as expected and that the asset is configured correctly. The analyst will use the dashboards created by the Operational Excellence Lead and the asset level dashboards to do this.

As the well is drilled the DDA will be responsible for updating the asset based on observed rig operations. The assets are going to be initially built based on the well prog but actual operations will dictate how the asset needs to be configured. Each new run will require some amount of preparation by the DDA to ensure that the correct BHA  or Casing string is activated.

Corva is designed to take in as much data as possible automatically but there are gaps in Corva’s ability to do this. As a result The DDA is responsible for entering data that Corva needs but is not able to automatically enter.

The DDA is also responsible for initial quality control. If the DDA notices that an app is not working as expected or that Corva has generated erroneous data the DDA is responsible for correcting the issue (or getting support staff involved to correct the issue) and then reprocessing data (rerunning the well) to correct the issue.
Common tasks to complete the job
**Connecting a well:**

When going through rigs using the Mission Control app a rig that has no active WITSML streams will look like this

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/9ef63bbd0afc.png:Figure 14]

Notice that all of the listed assets have a gray dot next to them and that the Current Activity is blank. No notes are displayed in this situation because there is no active asset so the Mission Control app doesn’t know what asset to select for displaying notes.
This typically occurs when a rig is moving or when a new rig has been added and operations on the first well have not commenced yet.

Alternatively, a rig in the Mission Control app that has a red message below the Current Activity that says “Updated at: (date time)” could indicate that a new asset needs to be connected to WITSML on this rig.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/5ae13f85b31a.png:Figure 37]

This red message indicates that the WITSML stream was last updated at that time and that time is earlier than the current time. This can be an issue with the WITSML stream or it can be that the rig is moving to another well. In either case the DDA will need to investigate to see if

the next well is ready to be connected. In the case with the red “Updated at” message, if the rig is moving to the next well, the DDA will need to either pause or complete the current asset depending on operations, which will be covered later in this document, before connecting the next well/asset. Each rig should have notes on the WITSML provider which can be viewed by selecting WITSML in the notes column.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/ded79f4ae30f.png:Figure 115]

If the WITSML provider has an EDR the DDA can look for the next well in the EDR. Otherwise the DDA will have to use PDS WITSML studio Desktop to look for the next well’s WITSML stream. In this example the EDR provider is Pason. Searching for part of the rig name shows that there is a well available in the EDR.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/a83ba83e19e1.png:Figure 102]

Since there is a “live” well in Pason the DDA would check to make sure that an asset for that well exists in Corva. Typically, assets for upcoming wells will appear on the Mission Control app

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/f4ffb77ec6ed.png:Figure 45]

If the asset for the well is not on the Mission Control app a quick search of the well name should be performed using the search function by clicking the magnifying glass icon at the top of the display

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/0b4ba3b00251.png:Figure 123]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/2fb831e3f4a5.png:Figure 36]

If an asset for the well does not exist in Corva the DDA should reach out to the Coordinators and ask them to request information to build the asset. Since an asset exists for the well in this example, the DDA will check to see that the asset is built and not just a shell asset. At a minimum the asset should have the Surface Equipment, Well Sections, Casing, a BHA, and a Fluid Check entered before connecting it to the WITSML stream; these can all be found in Wellhub after clicking on the asset. Ideally, the asset would also have Formations, a Well Plan, and a Map Location entered as well, however this information is not required before connecting the well.bv

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/d4d44eac23c9.png:Figure 10]

If the asset is built the DDA can move forward with connecting the asset to the WITSML stream. In the group of icons at the top right corner of the screen there is a gear shaped icon that says settings when the mouse cursor is hovered over it.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/f712123c8f19.png:Figure 58]

Clicking this icon will bring up the settings menu. The “+ New Stream” button is located in the “Well Streams” section.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/8bb62ac8cb9a.png:Figure 69]

Normally the DDA will use Stream Connector for connecting an asset to the WITSML stream.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/85763da1c5a0.png:Figure 59]

Stream Connector is where the connection between the asset in Corva and the WITSML stream will be configured. The portion of Stream Connector labeled “Select Target Well” is where the asset in Corva is selected

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/7455647c4932.png:Figure 16]

The portion of Stream Connector that is labeled “Connect to Source” will be the Stream Connector template (there should be notes on which template to use in the WITSML notes). The Stream Connector Template has the login credentials for the WITSML stream.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/5ad00a941eb5.png:Figure 12]

Once the Stream Connector template is selected the DDA can click the connect button which should now be blue.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/5e3a309042e4.png:Figure 67]

After clicking Connect, the drop downs under the “Select Well from Source” field should work. Depending on the WITSML provider there may be a large list of wells available, if that is the case it may be beneficial to type part of the well name in the Optional Well Filter. The options in these drop downs will correspond to how the WITSML stream shows up in PDS  WITSML Studio Desktop. Once the Well and Wellbore are selected the DDA can click the next button to select the Log

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/5ead40c2177c.png:Figure 30]

The WITSML notes should have details on which log(s) to select and what the frequency should be set to. If multiple logs are to be used the check box on the left must be checked and a frequency must be set for each log, however only one log should be set as the “Primary”. Once the logs are selected the DDA can click the next button. This will bring up the Time log Column Mapper. Every rig should have its own unique Column Mapper Template.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/d31d0d52b98b.png:Figure 72]
   
[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/2cca3dd31de4.png:Figure 128]

Once the Column Mapper template has been selected the DDA can click “Save Stream”

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/a0c04c850f7e.png:Figure 61]

This will take the DDA to the App Stream. At this point the stream is connected but not active. Notice how all of the apps are grayed out.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/8d18505790ce.png:Figure 21]

If the DDA needs to add a data frequency, data delay, or force start command before making the stream active this is the time to add those commands in the WITSML Source 2.0 app.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/530c357cbcc7.png:Figure 28]

The stream is ready to run at this point. The DDA can go back to the asset and set the Stream Status to Active, then click save. This will start the stream and the apps in Corva should start to turn on as the data starts coming in.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/358db17ce43e.png:Figure 52]

Once data starts to come in it is likely that there will be some data to catch up. While this data is catching up the DDA should leave the asset hidden from users. While the data is catching up there are several things the DDA should check to make sure Corva is functioning correctly.

• Are bit depth and hole depth updating? Check the EDR if available or PDS to see if Corva is displaying the correct depths. If the well had preset hole sections Corva’s Data Quality app may be preventing the correct hole depth from displaying. If the correct depths are not being displayed in Corva the DDA can go to the app stream and turn off the Data Quality temporarily until the correct depths are being displayed. To do this go to Wellhub>Overview and click on the DATA STREAMS drop down then select the App Stream in the Time section. From there find and click on the Data Quality app and toggle Bit Depth Connection and Hole Depth Connection to off then click the save icon.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/b8fa54b5252b.png:Figure 133]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/a1d026b61733.png:Figure 129]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/9e5d043289d5.png:Figure 76]
Once the correct depths are being displayed repeat the steps except toggle Bit Depth Connection and Hole Depth Connection to on.

Did BHA 1 activate? Typically the first operation will be to drill the surface hole section with BHA 1. There are several places where the DDA can check to see if BHA 1 is active but since this is a fresh connection the DDA should go to Wellhub>Drilling>Drillstrings. If BHA 1 activated there should be a green bell icon with the word Active next to it. While the DDA is looking at BHA 1 they can click the edit button and add the “Time In” and check the “Exact Time” check box. The time entered for “time in” should be the time that the stream started and if Corva is working correctly the time listed as the “Actual” time stamp. If the first drilling activity has been detected at this point the “Hole Depth In” can be entered as well, if not a note should be added to the Mission Control app saying the “BHA 1 in at needs to be updated”. Click save once finished.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/fc42c2df6159.png:Figure 132]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/7de265669d35.png:Figure 103]

• The time that BHA 1 activated should be the same time the WITSML stream started which should also be used for the “Rig Up” time. This can be entered either in Wellhub>Overview and click the edit button in the top right corner or in Wellhub>Drilling>Surface Equipment. If the first drilling activity has been detected the Spud Time should also be entered, if not a note should be added to the Mission Control app to “update the spud time”.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/3002f55ed358.png:Figure 95]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/1fbb1d9e949e.png:Figure 32]

• Once the data is caught up to real-time the asset should be made visible to clients. This can be done from Wellhub>Overview by clicking the icon that is 3 vertical dots and selecting “Show Well For Users”. After clicking this the “Hidden from Users” icon should go away.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/568c4c9accbd.png:Figure 63]

• After making the well visible the DDA can generate the Driller’s Roadmap if the asset has formations entered, a well plan uploaded, and an actual map location.The DDA will have to select offsets to use for the Driller’s Roadmap in Wellhub>Well>Offset Wells. Ideally, the offsets would be closest to the subject well so using the radius filter to get nearby wells is the preferred way to select offsets. If possible select a radius that selects 5-10 offsets, this way the DRM will have enough data to generate representative values but will not be overloaded with too much data causing long times to generate. Once the offsets are selected click the “SAVE OFFSET” button and go to the DRM app (should be on one of the asset level dashboards, likely the dashboard is labeled “Roadmap”).The DRM app will start generating on its own when opened. Once finished it should have values for each formation.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/17dc46e24b0d.png:Figure 83]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/6246ee2356c9.png:Figure 26]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/b81584fd659c.png:Figure 116]
At this point the asset should be good to go and the DDA should resume going through the wells on the Mission Control app.
Disconnecting a Well

When an asset in Corva shows that the WITSML stream is delayed this can mean that the rig has moved to the next well. The DDA should investigate rigs that either show up on the Mission Control app with an “Updated at: date time” message and/or showing a “WITSML server transmit delay” on an asset status app.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/3ea15b4e3835.png:Figure 122]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/56eb1dff3349.png:Figure 91]

If the DDA finds that the stream went offline after a casing run the rig is likely moving to the next well. If this was after the production casing run the DDA can assume the well has been “completed”, if this was after a surface or intermediate casing run (or occasionally T/A operations) the DDA can assume that the rig will come back to this asset at a later date and set the well to “paused”. To do this the DDA will need to determine the time the WITSML stream stopped and enter that time as the rig release date in Wellhub>Overview>Well Information or Welllhub>Surface Equipment. The easiest way to find the time that the WITSML stream stopped is to use the “Updated at” time from the Mission control app.

Once the rig release date is entered and saved the DDA should either set the Stream Status in Wellhub>Overview>Well Information to “Complete” or “Paused” then click the save button.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/a64570c6a044.png:Figure 35]

If the DDA sets the well to “complete” the QC team will add this well to their workflow so the DDA may want to do a quick check of the asset for things that can be fixed before the QC team looks at it.
Getting Corva ready for the next run:

The DDA is responsible for preparing Corva for the next run. This should be done when the DDA sees that a rig has begun tripping out. The DDA will need to use their judgment to determine if the next run will be casing or a BHA. The Mission Control app should have most of the information required to make an educated guess on whether or not the next run will be another BHA or a casing run. The column labeled “% Complete” will have the section TD and planned casing depths listed. If the hole depth is significantly less than the section TD and casing depth then the DDA will likely need to add a BHA with the same size drill bit.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/99445552c90b.png:Figure 56]

If the hole depth is near the section TD but significantly short of the casing point the DDA will likely need to add a BHA but should check to see if a bit size change occurs for the next hole section and will likely need to update the section TD to the actual values.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/69f92455e769.png:Figure 125]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/668d31e0af24.png:Figure 50]

If the hole depth is close to the section TD and the next casing depth the DDA will likely need to prepare Corva for a casing run by updating the hole section and casing depths to the actual values.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/d1060f9d73d2.png:Figure 97]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/8662ff1900cc.png:Figure 57]

The DDA should verify what the next operation is if possible using comments in the traces app, operations summaries from the DDRs, operations summaries from the mud reports, and/or any other source available.

**Adding Place Holder BHAs***
*

If the DDA has determined that the next run will be a BHA a place holder BHA should be added to the asset while tripping out. The easiest way to add a BHA is to copy another BHA. If the DDA has determined that the next BHA will use the same size bit as the current run the DDA can simply copy the current BHA. This can be done by going to Wellhub>Drilling>Drillstrings and clicking the blue plus sign icon then selecting “Copy from other asset” in the menu that pops up.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/5a68723d69a8.png:Figure 140]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/9f114b1cd468.png:Figure 48]

The Copy Drillingstrings/BHAs wizard will pop up. The selections will default to the asset that the operation was started from. To copy the previous BHA the DDA will not need to change anything in this wizard before clicking next.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/8ec2502fbd70.png:Figure 18]

The next screen will ask the DDA to select the BHAs to copy. The DDA should select the current BHA then click next.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/18870a8b885d.png:Figure 6]

On the next screen the DDA should change the “Drillstring/BHA Number” to the desired number (for a drilling BHA this should be the next whole number, in this example BHA 2 was copied so the DDA should enter 3). The DDA should also change the “Hole Depth In” to the well’s current hole depth. Corva uses the Hole Depth In as a trigger to activate the BHA, so if the hole depth is not updated Corva may activate the copied BHA before the desired time.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/82fc5bdf4dd3.png:Figure 111]

When the DDA clicks done Corva will make a copy of the BHA and remove the bit, motor, and RSS labels, replacing them with the If the label “Placeholder BHA”. When the DDA receives the actual BHA file these can be updated with the rest of the BHA.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/ef98832f52d0.png:Figure 13]

quiz.question: Before connecting a well in Connecting a well, what must you verify?

options.text: Confirm trace labels, units, and channel mappings match the EDR configuration
Use default mappings to save time

quiz.explanation: Correct data mapping is essential for accurate real-time monitoring.

sourceRef.evidenceSnippet: Correct data mapping is essential for accurate real-time monitoring.

quiz.question: A WITSML trace in Connecting a well shows unexpected units. What should you do?

options.text: Reference the PDS WITSML viewer to confirm the correct units before proceeding

quiz.explanation: Unit verification prevents data errors that affect all downstream calculations.

sourceRef.evidenceSnippet: Unit verification prevents data errors that affect all downstream calculations.

quiz.question: In Connecting a well, what ensures accurate Well Name data?

options.text: Verifying Well Name against the official drilling program or wellbore diagram

quiz.explanation: Well Name accuracy in Connecting a well is critical for calculations and app reliability.

sourceRef.evidenceSnippet: Well Name accuracy in Connecting a well is critical for calculations and app reliability.

content.body:
*Updating Hole Sections
*

If the DDA has determined that another BHA should be added next but the bit size is different from the current run the steps for copying a BHA are the same except the DDA will have to select a different well from the Copy Drillingstrings/BHAs wizard (ideally one drilled by the same rig so the BHA configuration will be close to the actual BHA). Additionally, the DDA should update the hole section depth to match where the hole size will change. This can be done in Wellhub>Well>Well Sections. Both the bottom depth of the current section and the top depth of the next section should be updated.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/878de479e431.png:Figure 1]

*Getting Corva Ready for Casing
*

If the DDA has determined that casing will be run next, a BHA will not need to be added but the hole sections and casing depth will need to be updated. The casing depth should match the hole section bottom depth and not the planned casing shoe depth. This is because the casing depth works similarly to the depth in on BHAs to trigger casing automatically. The casing can be found in Wellhub>Drilling>Casing & Risers. To edit the casing click the pencil shaped icon next to the casing entry.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/f17d8c59fcfa.png:Figure 108]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/eeaae35223c0.png:Figure 113]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/243b03c07ca5.png:Figure 134]

*Getting Corva ready for the BHA after a Casing Run
*

With the exception of liner runs and casing runs on floating offshore rigs there will not be a trip out for casing runs. Therefore the DDA will need to enter a BHA for Corva to activate once the casing has been landed (or very nearly landed). The DDA should wait to add the placeholder BHA until it is apparent that the rig will get casing to bottom as there is built in logic that may activate the next place holder BHA prematurely if the rig trips out and back in. Typically, a rig will run casing, leave the bit depth at the casing shoe during the cement job and while waiting on cement, then reset bit depth to surface when they are ready to trip in with the next drilling BHA. If the DDA has entered a placeholder BHA before the rig resets their bit depth Corva will automatically activate this BHA when the bit depth resets to surface (or near surface).

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/90be65388f9d.png:Figure 53]
The DDA will need to check the hole section sizes to verify what the next BHA size should be, then copy a BHA from another asset with the correct bit size.

*Activating BHAs and Casing*When a BHA or casing is activated in Corva an “Actual” timestamp will be added to the BHA or casing which can be seen when editing a BHA or casing.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/0e8ec5a97998.png:Figure 93]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/9179221b456e.png:Figure 15]

The DDA is responsible for ensuring that BHAs and casing activate at the right time. Corva has logic built in to activate BHAs and casing automatically however, certain rig operations can trick the logic causing the BHA/casing to activate early or not activate at all. For this reason DDAs need to monitor assets that are tripping out. When the rig is at surface with the current run the best practice is to go ahead and activate the next run by opening either the BHA or casing that is to be run next, adding a “Time In” timestamp, checking the “Exact time” check box, and clicking “IMMEDIATELY FORCE”. Using the “IMMEDIATELY FORCE” button does what it sounds like; it saves any changes and forces the BHA or casing to activate. In most cases this will be the best practice.
Exceptions to using “IMMEDIATELY FORCE”

• If the WITSML stream is delayed. If for any reason the data in Corva is not up to date (could be a rerun asset, a historical upload, the data could be catching up from the stream being recently connected, or there could have been connectivity issues) and the DDA knows what the approximate time of the run changing, the DDA should enter the “Time In” timestamp and check the “Exact time” checkbox, then click save. When the data catches up to the “Time In” timestamp Corva will activate that run

• If Corva already activated the correct run on its own. This typically occurs after a casing run when the bit depth resets, but this can happen if the rig starts tripping in again before the DDA has a chance to activate the next run. Since the correct run is already active the DDA will not need to force it to activate, only updating the “Time In” timestamp and checking the “Exact time” check box is required. Note: Forcing a BHA or casing that has already been activated will cause some of the apps to malfunction and this will require rerunning the well to fix.

quiz.question: While calibrating in Updating Hole Sections, you find data inconsistencies. What is the correct approach?

content.body: Calibrating BHAs:

Once a BHA has been run into the hole and has drilled 200’ (on hole sections with a TD deeper than 2000’) and the BHA has been built using an actual BHA tally (do not calibrate placeholder BHAs) the DDA will need to calibrate the Hookload Broomstick model and the Circulating Pressure Loss Model (CPL). The calibration tool in the BHA edit should closely resemble the Hookload Broomstick app and the Circulating Pressure Loss app. On occasion the calibration tool will not display data, in that case the Hookload Broomstick app and Circulating Pressure Loss app will need to be used to calibrate the BHA, the only difference with using the apps vs the calibration tool is the changes will need to be saved then the apps will need to be allowed time to update and reflect the changes, the calibration tool will display the values before saving and will not require time to update. 
[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/775098eb908f.png:Figure 55]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/86f48d3e730c.png:Figure 17]

To access the calibration tool the DDA will need to go to Wellhub>Drilling>Drillstrings and click on the edit button of the active BHA, the calibration button will be at the bottom of the BHA.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/94451a92425f.png:Figure 94]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/8f863eddbf97.png:Figure 9]

After clicking the calibrate button a pop up will appear that has check boxes for what calibration tools to bring up. The CPL calibration should be calibrated first as the reactive force from the flow is used to shift the rotating line on the hookload model when viscous drag is turned on. The DDA can select both calibration tools at the same time if desired however, the calibration tools will load faster if used one at a time.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/1f18e7be25d6.png:Figure 87]

When calibrating the CPL the goal is to make the Predicted SPP as close as possible to the Actual SPP. The Percentage displayed in parentheses is the percent difference between the predicted and actual values, this is the value that is represented in the histogram bars at the bottom of the app and calibration tool. The bars will be green if the divergence is less than 10%, yellow if the divergence is between 10% and 25%, and red if the divergence is more than 25%.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/f80f6c66baf1.png:Figure 65]
Inputs that affect the circulating pressure loss model include:
• BHA ODs and IDs
• Casing IDs
• Open hole size
• Mud properties
• Surveys
• Bit jets
• Motor specs and pressure loss
• MWD pressure loss
• RSS pressure loss
• Agitator pressure loss

Initially the DDA can assume everything was entered correctly and should start with manipulating the pressure loss settings on the motor, MWD, RSS, and agitator if included. The pressure loss entries on these components should start out with the flow rate at the minimum value of the motor flow rate range and the pressure loss set at 100psi for the RSS, MWD, and agitator, and 150psi for the motor. If the predicted pressure needs to be increased the pressure loss values can be increased (if the flow rate is already set to the minimum value). If the predicted pressure needs to be decreased the flow rate can be increased within the operating range of the motor (the pressure losses should be set to 150psi for the motor and 100pis for all other components with a pressure loss before increasing the flow rate). If the BHA does not have a motor the flow rate range for the string is normally reported on the BHA tally in the MWD comments. The flow rate used should match for all components that have a pressure loss entry. If the DDA is not able to get the CPL divergence within 10% by adjusting the pressure loss and flow rate values on these components the other things that affect predicted SPP should be verified. .If the DDA is still not able to get the CPL divergence within 10% after verifying ODs/IDs, mud, surveys, bit jets, and motor specs the engineering specialist should be notified

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/76a0f000335f.png:Figure 118]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/8d2a8ab1efd8.png:Figure 4]

Once the CPL is calibrated the DDA can work on the hookload broomstick model calibration. The DDA will be adjusting the model so the Rotating Off Bottom points will be landing on the Rotating line. In most situations the viscous drag adjustment should be turned on.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/ce7a65c23ad9.png:Figure 25]

sections.title: Inputs that affect the hookload model

content.body: Inputs that affect the hookload model:
• Pipe weights
• Block weight
• Mud properties
• Surveys

To begin calibrating the hookload model the DDA should verify the value entered for block weight in Wellhub>Drilling>Surface Equipment reflects the in slips hooklad value, which can be observed in the traces app at connections (several connections should be checked in case there is fluctuation in the sensor reading).

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/bd7e49fc885a.png:Figure 27]

Once the hookload is confirmed the DDA may want to confirm that surveys are present and current and that the mud weight in the most recent fluid check is correct. Then the DDA can go back into the active BHA and manipulate the pipe weights to make the rotating off bottom points line up with the rotating line on the hookload model. Unless the well is still very shallow and there is a lot of HWDP in the BHA tally, manipulating the drill pipe weight is going to make the most difference in the hookload model; this is where the DDA should normally focus their calibration efforts although HWDP and collar weights can be manipulated to shift the model if needed. All entries for the same type of pipe should use the same weight.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/4bfa0a3e1963.png:Figure 100]

After making changes to the pipe weights the DDA should check the calibration tool to see if the changes corrected the model. Once the rotating line on the model is landing on the actual rotating points the DDA can click the save button which should close the BHI edit. At this point the Calibrate BHA button can be checked to show the clients that the BHA has been calibrated.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/a4a4f2e4e199.png:Figure 119]

Once this button has been clicked a pop up asking “are you sure it’s been calibrated”, if the analyst clicks “ok” the icon will change to say Calibrated and include a time when it was calibrated and the name of the analyst that clicked the button.
[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/3cdb01244939.png:Figure 79]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/595713c27c7f.png:Figure 3]

content.body: Calibrating Casing Runs:

The DDA should check all Hookload Broomstick models for casing runs to ensure the points being plotted are following the model. However, for surface and intermediate hole sections many rigs will run in closed ended and the slack off points will only approach the model after the rig fills the pipe. Additionally, the casing weights should not be manipulated in the same way that drill pipe can be, therefore surface and intermediate casing strings will not have very many variables that can be adjusted to make the points line up. Casing strings are often not rotated down, especially surface and intermediate strings, so the slack off points will likely be the majority of the points on the hookload broomstick and observed friction factors can vary depending on hole conditions. As a result, calibrating surface and intermediate casing strings is not required, however the DDA should strive to make the model as accurate as possible (verify mud weight, block weight, casing weight, and surveys).

Unlike surface and Intermediate casing runs, production casing runs do need to be calibrated. This is because many clients will run an airlock sub (ALS) in their production casing string, which causes the casing between the ALS and the casing shoe to float. This is done to help reduce the low side drag in long production laterals. The same limitations apply to calibrating production casing the addition and placement of an ALS will dramatically change the shape of the hookload model.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/84d452081898.png:Figure 64]
 
[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/84d452081898.png:Figure 127]

If it looks like there might be an ALS being run in the casing string the DDA should use the Coms SOP to figure out who to email for a casing tally and send an email requesting the casing tally. Typically, the ALS will be run near the kick off point. Therefore the DDA can estimate where the ALS should be located in the string even if a casing tally has not been received. To do this the DDA will go to the Wellhub>Drilling>Actual Surveys and find the approximate depth of the KOP based on where the inclination starts to increase. The length of floating casing can be approximated by subtracting the well’s total depth from the depth of the KOP. This is the amount of casing that should be placed between the float shoe and the ALS. Then the DDA will need to set the inside mud weight of that casing to 0ppg (leaving the entry blank will use the density of the mud present in the most recent fluid check).

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/7bc0c5763e16.png:Figure 107]

Unlike the BHA calibration tool the DDA will need to save changes before opening the calibration tool. Once the model is shifted enough that the slack off points are landing in the fan created by the slack off friction factor lines the DDA is done calibrating the casing, but should check back when casing is near bottom to see if the placement of the ALS needs to be adjusted.
Data Entry:

Any data that is required for apps to function correctly that is not automatically being pulled into Corva will need to be entered by the DDA. Progress is being made towards pulling more data in automatically but for various reasons the automation may not work in every instance. Additionally, the DDA is responsible for requesting any data that is required but has not yet been received.
Data that commonly needs to be entered manually in Corva includes:
• Mud reports/fluid checks
• BHA and casing tallies
• Surveys
• Well plans/target change lines/drilling window updates

*Mud Reports/Fluid Checks
*

At the moment, most mud reports don’t parse, although efforts are being made to get more of them  parsing and automatically entered. The DDA needs to be looking for mud reports throughout their tour in the [data@corva.ai](mailto:data@corva.ai) inbox. When a mud report comes in the DDA needs to upload the document to  the “Mud Reports” folder found in Wellhub>Overview in the documents section. This can be done by dragging and dropping in the folder or clicking the “+ CREATE” button and selecting “Upload Document”.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/7778a72fd5f1.png:Figure 131]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/982868a7fe5d.png:Figure 34]

Then the DDA will need to enter the information in the mud report as a new fluid check in Wellhub>Drilling>Fluid Checks by pressing the blue plus sign icon on the right side of the screen and selecting “Add New” from the drop down.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/f65a6383f4a9.png:Figure 82]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/4a4cce88a8c8.png:Figure 112]

The DDA will need to enter the Mud Type, Density, Date, Depth MD, Viscosity PV, and the Viscosity YP. If the Rheometer Readings are included the DDA should enter those values as well by clicking the blue plus sign icon at the bottom left of the screen. The DDA should also do a quick QC to make sure the rheometer readings do not conflict with the entered PV and YP; PV should be equal to the 600 RPM reading minus the 300 RPM reading, and YP should be equal to the PV value minus the 300 RPM reading. If the rheometer values conflict with the PV/YP values do not enter the rheometer readings. Once finished click the save button at the bottom of the page.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/874e1f8ba698.png:Figure 110]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/ac0ce2a1d142.png:Figure 74]

If no mud reports are being sent to the data inbox the DDA should look for this data in reports that are being received (DDRs commonly have fluid checks included), and consult the coms SOP for instructions on how to request the data from the client.

*BHAs and Casing Tallies
*

BHAs and casing tallies are typically sent to the [data@corva.ai](mailto:data@corva.ai) inbox, but are occasionally sent via Intercom. Most of the time actual BHA and casing tallies are sent early enough that the DDA can add the files to the asset and make a card in Trello for off-duty hands to enter for supplementary pay.  If this is the case the DDA should go to Wellhub>Overview and create a folder for the casing or BHA file(s) by pressing “+ CREATE”, selecting “Folder” from the drop down menu,  entering a name that is representative of the run (either BHA X, or X.XX” casing) and clicking save.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/f4e60f20a5bb.png:Figure 120]
 
[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/38383d76c8b0.png:Figure 62]

Then a card can be created in Trello by using the template in either the “BHA” or “In House” columns.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/58d0d9e9b6f2.png:Figure 38]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/04b2ed56eeed.png:Figure 43]

The labels should be replaced with the data and then the “Create card” button can be clicked. Once clicked the card will pop up and the DDA can drag and drop the BHA or casing tally files to the card. The card can be closed once the files have been uploaded.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/117ad5ebe805.png:Figure 41]

However, if the rig is going to commence drilling before the BHA can be entered by off-duty hands, or the casing run is nearing bottom, the on-duty hand will have to update the BHA or casing run. For BHAs, motor specs need to be correct before drilling starts because this will affect the MSE values that get stored to the database. Additionally the items that affect the CPL model need to be entered before drilling starts as these are used to calculate the predicted SPP value which is also stored in the database. For casing runs, the hookload model will no longer update if there is no pipe movement. A rerun is required to fix these issues if not addressed in time. Therefore, the DDA may be required to update BHA and casing from time to time.

content.body:
*Manual Surveys
*

Corva is designed to ingest surveys from the trajectory object in the WITSML stream, but in some circumstances the trajectory object may not have data (MWD/DD not entering surveys) or it may not have accurate data (MWD/DD publishing check shots to trajectory object). Some progress has been made in getting surveys to automatically parse form the data inbox when the trajectory object can’t be used, but if that can not be setup for the specific well the DDA will need to do manual survey entry. In the situation where check shots are being uploaded the DDA may be able to turn full update off and manually remove the check shot or overwrite the existing surveys with the approved surveys from the data inbox. If this can be made to work the DDA will not have to constantly update surveys manually but may need to clean them up intermittently. From Wellhub>Overview click on the data streams drop down and select the time log then find the Corva WITSML Trajectory Log App in the App Stream. 
[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/ca53f59a8d47.png:Figure 20]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/4bd7f5714441.png:Figure 96]

Then toggle the “Full Update” switch to off and click the save button.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/971f6d6a6b71.png:Figure 44]

Once full update has been turned off Corva should only pull in new surveys deeper than the last survey that it has already pulled in. The DDA can now go to Wellhub>Drilling>Actual Surveys, remove the bad surveys/check shots by clicking the edit button and removing the bad surveys then saving. 
[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/efced06c9340.png:Figure 124]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/f665ab2597a4.png:Figure 130]

It is very likely that the DDA will not know which surveys are the check shots and which surveys are the approved surveys without consulting the approved surveys that have been emailed to the inbox. If that is the case it may be faster to import the surveys rather than hunt for the bad ones. To import surveys the DDA will need to copy the survey depths, inclination, and azimuth columns from the document contained in the email to a new excel spreadsheet (just the values, no column labels); survey depth should be the first column, inclination the second, and azimuth  third. The new excel file should be saved in a location that is easy to find and with a name that the DDA can remember.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/50970b079daa.png:Figure 40]

The DDA can go back to the Actual surveys and click the import button at the top then click the “UPLOAD A DOCUMENT” button on the next screen, then find the surveys file and click “Open”. 
[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/bd9d1c395537.png:Figure 42]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/0ab89dacb4d1.png:Figure 70]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/7c347d5ae64c.png:Figure 86]

Once Corva uploads the surveys it will give the DDA a chance to edit them; if there is a tie-in station this should be entered here. Once everything is good to go the DDA can click save at the bottom. 
[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/09684ed1c221.png:Figure 106]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/50581195fe32.png:Figure 138]
Now only surveys deeper than the last entry should be automatically pulled from the WITSML stream.

If surveys are not being stored to the trajectory object they will need to be updated manually in a similar manner. Depending on how frequently the DDA is able to update the surveys it may be easiest to upload surveys as above or, if there haven’t been very many surveys taken since the last time the DDA went to update surveys, it may be faster to just type in the new surveys. A good rule of thumb is more than 5 new surveys will probably be fastest to just upload a file. To add a new survey open up the edit in Actual Surveys and click the blue plus sign icon; this will add a new line where the DDA can enter the survey depth, inclination, and azimuth values. Once finished adding surveys the DDA can click the save button.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/fe25734dfc49.png:Figure 121]

content.body: Updating Well Plans

Occasionally the planned well trajectory will change and an updated well plan will need to be entered, usually at new well sections or if a side track/bypass is to be drilled. Uploading the new well plan is very similar to uploading surveys except it will be done from Wellhub>Well>Well Plan. Follow the same steps as uploading surveys to the point where the file has been loaded but not saved.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/49d437402189.png:Figure 136]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/93f7d055c948.png:Figure 33]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/9c687fef09b9.png:Figure 85]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/4357c3e7a882.png:Figure 54]

At this point the DDA will need to enter the Plan Name, the Vertical Section Azimuth, and Tie In (if applicable). Then click the save button at the bottom.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/f72746a1e480.png:Figure 75]
**DDA Workflow**
Some of the DDA’s tasks are more critical than others. While on tour the DDA should prioritize tasks in the following order:
• Customer facing tech support including Intercom, responding to emails, and answering phone calls - This is a feature that sets Corva apart from its competitors.
• Well connections - Customers will quickly notice if their data is not available in Corva but is available from other sources like the EDR.

• BHA and casing activations - Activating the correct BHA or casing at the correct time keeps the apps running correctly and displaying accurate data. Missed activations or incorrect activations will require reprocessing an entire well’s data to fix.
• Calibrations - This also keeps the app running correctly and displaying accurate data, however this task tends to be less time sensitive than the aforementioned items.
• Manual data entry - This also keeps the app running correctly and displaying accurate data, however this task tends to be less time sensitive than the aforementioned items.

Because most of these tasks are event based the DDA needs to stay organized as task switching is frequently required. Since customer facing tech support is the DDAs #1 priority the DDA should keep a window with Intercom open at all times with audible notifications turned on. To help keep track of well connections the DDA can use the WITSML provider’s EDR (if available) to monitor when new wells start. For clients that do not have an EDR the DDA will need to keep track of the wells that are offline and have a process for checking PDS on a regular basis to ensure well connections are made in a timely manner; going through the wells in the  Mission Control app on a regular time interval is useful for this. To ensure that BHAs and casing strings get activated on time, it is recommended that the DDA should have a window open with a tab for each rig that is tripping out, however any method the DDA can devise to reliably activate BHAs and casing strings at surface is acceptable. The Mission Control and the Well Check Up apps have errors that will let the DDA know if the next run is prepared (the “Add a PH BHA” error). Paying attention to this error can further help the DDA with activations as this indicates that Corva does not have something to activate on its own if it detects the rig has started to trip back in. BHA calibrations are somewhat less time sensitive and there are errors in the Mission Control and Well Check Up apps that can be used to draw the DDA’s attention. Beyond the event based tasks that were covered above, the DDA should go through all of their rigs once every 2 hours to see if any conditions have changed and to update the handover notes in the Mission Control app as needed. The DDA is not required to conform to a set workflow so long as these tasks are completed and prioritized correctly. The main tools provided to the DDA are the Mission Control app, Well Check Up app, and Company Dashboards.
Mission Control/Automated Hand Over

The Mission Control app took the place of the old excel based handover notes and was called Automated Handover when initially released. It was originally intended as an interactive set of handover notes that would automatically store values from Corva that were previously manually entered by the DDAs to help them keep track of rig operations, to do lists, WITSML connection notes, and upcoming wells. Since then more features have been added with the intention of streamlining the DDAs workflow (trying to use fewer clicks to get information the DDA needs and fewer clicks to get to locations the DDA needs to enter information). In addition to keeping notes the Mission Control app also has filters and a search function that are designed to help the DDA quickly find notes on a well and navigate to that well.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/305475e336e3.png:Figure 137]

The main body of the Mission Control app is broken up into rows and columns. Each row represents a rig. The Operator column contains the name of the operator using the rig, the Fusion status (parsed reports) and the Data Request button. The DDA can filter by the operator to help find rigs for a certain client/operator. The data request button should be used anytime a request for information is sent so that the data request can be logged. The Fusion status will let the DDA know if parsing is working for automatic data entry.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/eb5c39bf606e.png:Figure 88]

The Rig name column contains the rig name and a space to note what operations dashboard the rig is present on. The DDA can type the rig name in the search bar to filter by rig. To edit the dashboard note the DDA can simply click on the note to place the cursor and begin editing, any changes will be saved immediately. 
[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/c212ce98d35a.png:Figure 92]

The Asset Status/Well-Pad column and the Asset Number column are tied together and contain a list of assets assigned to the rig and operator. Assets can be removed by hovering over the entry in either column and clicking the Delete button (the trashcan shaped icon). If an asset exists in Corva for this Operator/Rig but it is not already in the list the DDA can add it by clicking the Add Asset button (the blue plus sign icon) at the bottom of the list in the Asset Status/Well-Pad column.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/72b6aa2de980.png:Figure 81]
      
[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/a03fa4445ae0.png:Figure 51]

The green check mark icon indicates which asset/well is selected. The column to the right of the Asset Number column will display data for the selected asset. Whatever well is active on this rig will default to being the selected asset. If there is not an active well for this rig the Mission control will not select an asset by default and the columns to the right will be blank.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/8deeba34d4fa.png:Figure 60]

The colored dots to the left of the well name indicate the stream status of the asset. Green indicates that the asset is active. Grey indicates that the asset is idle (typically the case if the asset hasn’t been connected yet). A yellow dot indicates the asset is paused (the well should have data and a stream but operations have been suspended on that well before the well has been completed). A blue dot indicates the well has been completed (the well has been TDd operations are finished). The DDA will normally only keep the most recently completed asset on the mission control app (in case some data from the previous well needs to be referenced), to prevent the app from becoming cluttered. However, if an asset is being rerun the DDA may want to keep the completed original asset on the app until the rerun has caught up. 
[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/85934e5b4f86.png:Figure 78]

Assets that are active (or had been active) but are not visible to clients will show up indented and slightly grayed out. These are typically rerun assets.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/78446b4770e4.png:Figure 66]

The asset numbers in the Asset Number column are also links to the asset. This is typically the fastest way for the DDA to get to the asset to make changes.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/7ee91a1efc9b.png:Figure 11]

The Current Activity/Note column has current detected activity which is automatically populated, and the DDAs manually entered notes for the current rig activity.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/142c8f58f458.png:Figure 7]

In the current activity section the simplified rig activity, basic run information, current hole size, and last updated time are displayed. The simplified rig activity will either be DA (drill ahead), TIH (trip in hole), POOH (pull out of hole), or Off Bottom (off bottom but with no movement). The basic run information will display what run is currently active. This will either be a BHA or casing. If the run is a BHA and it is a placeholder BHA it will show up as “PH BHA #”, but if the BHA has been updated it will show up as “BHA #”. If the BHA has drilled more than 200’ there will either be a red ‘X’ or a green check mark in front of the BHA. This indicates whether or not the BHA has been calibrated (red ‘X’ = not calibrated, green check mark = calibrated). If the run is a casing string the casing size will be displayed. The last entry on the top row is the current hole size. The second row will display the last time data has been updated for this asset. If the last updated time is within the last 15min this line will show up in gray, between 15min and 30min it will show up in yellow, and more than 30min it will show up in red.

The notes section is for manually entered notes related to the rig activity that will help the DDA keep track of operations. A good practice is for the DDA to include the current activity in the notes. This way, when the DDA looks at this rig next they can quickly see if the activity from the last time they looked at this rig matches the current detected activity. Changes in activity are important because it usually means the DDA needs to prepare Corva for the next operation. For example if the previous time the DDA looked at a specific rig the activity was DA (drilling ahead) but the current activity is showing POOH (pulling out of hole), the DDA will likely need to either add a placeholder BHA or update the casing and hole section depths to prepare for the next run. If the previous activity was TIH (trip in hole), but the current activity is DA (drill ahead), the DDA may need to calibrate the BHA. If the previous activity was POOH (pull out of hole), but the current activity is TIH (trip in hole) the DDA may need to activate the next run or check to see that Corva has activated the correct run.

To add a note the DDA can click the blue plus sign icon in this column.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/297c93cc8c03.png:Figure 117]

If the DDA would like to edit or delete an existing note, hovering the cursor over the note will reveal an icon with 3 dots and clicking this icon will pull up a menu with the options “Edit” and “Delete”.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/bd84325f7132.png:Figure 49]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/66d5c3e7c5d2.png:Figure 135]

If the DDA selects “Delete” a pop up will appear asking “Are you sure?”. If the DDA selects “Edit” a pop up will appear with a field that can be edited and a blue arrow icon in the bottom right corner; this is the save button.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/d2f61dd87b34.png:Figure 46]

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/e993fe73d095.png:Figure 24]

The next column to the right is the Bit Depth/Hole Depth column. The top line is the bit depth and the bottom line is the hole depth. This cell is color coded based on the detected activity; blue = DA, green = TIH, yellow = POOH, gray = Off Bottom, black = undefined.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/ab3c0c25b7bf.png:Figure 19]

The next column is the % Complete column. This column will show what hole section the rig is in followed by a series of bar graphs (the graphs will vary slightly depending on if the current run is a BHA or casing), at the bottom there is a histogram of activity codes for the last 12hrs. The hole section is as it appears in Wellhub>Well>Well Sections.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/ea60109eb91a.png:Figure 114]
The bar graphs visually show how close the rig is to certain depths. If a BHA is active the graphs will be as follows:
Section TD - this is a visual comparison between the current hole depth and the next planned hole section TD found in Wellhub>Well>Well Sections

Calibration - a visual comparison between the current hole depth and the BHA in at depth + 200’. When this bar is full the check mark or the X will appear in the Current Activity column of mission control indicating whether or not the BHA has been calibrated.
Casing Point - a visual comparison between the current hole depth and the planned casing point found in Wellhub>Drilling>Casing & Riser

Well TD - a visual comparison between the current hole depth and the planned well TD. This would be the bottom depth of the last hole section found in Wellhub>Well>Well Sections

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/712cd670f73e.png:Figure 90]
If casing is active the graph will be as follows:

Casing TD -  a visual comparison between the current bit depth and the casing depth found in Wellhub>Drilling>Casing & Riser. At this point, since casing is active, the Casing TD depth should match the current hole depth.

Casing Point - a visual comparison between the current hole depth and the casing depth found in Wellhub>Drilling>Casing & Riser. Again, since casing is active, the Casing TD depth should match the current hole depth and this bar should be full.

Well TD  - a visual comparison between the current hole depth and the planned well TD

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/de81b1dfd9af.png:Figure 23]

The rig activity histogram displays color coded stripes that represent the rig activity codes over the past 12 hours. Once the DDA is familiar with some of the more common color codes this histogram allows the DDA to have a sense of what the rig operations have been over the past tour. Just above the histogram the current rig activity is written out and just to the right of the histogram a colored dot representing the current activity color code is present.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/c0c3b3e27bb5.png:Figure 139]

The next column is the Notes column. It is broken up into 3 tabs. The first tab is labeled Wells and is tied to the active asset. This is where the DDA should record their to-do notes for the selected asset and any other information relevant to keeping this asset running correctly in Corva.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/c821c91d75b6.png:Figure 104]

The next tab is labeled Rig. This is a fairly new addition but it is intended to be used for notes that are specific to the rig, not just the well.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/2f8f98608060.png:Figure 39]

The next tab is labeled WITSML. This is intended to be used for notes related to connecting the WITSML stream. This may include which stream connector template to use, which column mapper template to use, which log(s) to connect to and what frequency they should be set to, notes on mnemonics that may change, and any JSON commands that may need to be added after connecting a well.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/dd6b5676ca6c.png:Figure 77]

The next column over is labeled Errors. This column will display the QC score and the errors from the Well Check Up app. The errors, error status colors, and error icons will be discussed further in the Well Check Up app section. The DDA can click on the error just like in the Well Check Up app.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/4dfc90d17475.png:Figure 109]

The last column is the Reviewed column. This column has a button that says “REVIEW”.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/ebdb9dee23af.png:Figure 29]

When the DDA clicks this button the mission control app records the bit depth and the time when the button was clicked, and records the name of the user who clicked the button.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/2d80ea732717.png:Figure 126]
The purpose of this is similar to adding an activity note with the rig’s current activity. The next time the asset is reviewed the bit depth can be compared to the current bit depth.

The Mission Control app can be used by itself to quickly go through the DDAs wells to look for changes in operations and record notes. However, the Mission Control app is designed to be used in conjunction with the Company dashboards and the Well Check Up app to find and organize the tasks that the DDA needs to complete.

Use the previous plan as template
Make changes based on field data

content.body: Company Dashboards

The Operational Excellence Lead will create company dashboards for the DDAs to use. These will typically have 1-4 rigs on them and will usually have the same 6 apps on them. These 6 apps should draw the DDA’s attention to tasks they will need to complete and issues they will need to remediate. The 6 apps that are typically found on the company dashboards are:
• Asset Status
• Hookload Broomstick Plot
• Circulating Pressure Loss
• Torque Broomstick Plot
• Directional Divergence
• MSE vs Depth

*Asset Status App*The Asset Status app should display the status for the active well on the rig it is set up for. Some sections of this app will be redundant to the Mission Control app. These sections can quickly be used to ensure the correct asset is selected on the Mission Control app and that there is only one active and visible asset for this rig.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/6e5e8d7b0b3a.png:Figure 141]

In addition to this information the Asset Status app will also display the current mud weight, the last survey depth, and the most recent 24hr ops summary and look ahead.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/c03235e7655e.png:Figure 89]

At the far left of the Asset Status app there is a color coded bar. The color of the bar will indicate the stream status and if certain errors are present. If the bar is green it means the stream is active and there are no errors, if the bar is yellow it means an error is present (the error will be indicated by an icon that will appear on the bar), red indicates that the most recent data is more than 60 min old (by default,this can be adjusted in the app settings), and gray indicates that there is no active stream.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/c46fb0857048.png:Figure 80]
The icons in the colored status bar have the following meanings:

Last mud report is out of date - 
[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/69a8baac1554.png:Figure 71]

Surveys are behind - 
[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/c0a603d809c2.png:Figure 22]

BHA not calibrated - 
[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/099806ee432f.png:Figure 31]

WITSML stream is delayed - 
[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/255f688e6926.png:Figure 99]

Operation compliance issue - 
[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/25c75fe8bd2d.png:Figure 47]
(does not require DDA’s attention) -

*Hookload Broomstick app
*

The Hookload Broomstick app should default to displaying the hookload model and the collected real data points for the current run. The DDA is responsible for calibrating the model to match up with the real rotating off bottom data points (ROB points). This app has been included in the dashboards so that the DDAs can quickly see if their calibration is lining up with the real data points.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/d431fbd6a7ac.png:Figure 84]
      
[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/b1b9359a0ba0.png:Figure 8]

Additionally, the DDA can use this app to verify surveys are up to date and accurate using the DLS line. If the DLS line goes to the bottom of the model the surveys are caught up. If there are large spikes in the DLS line it is possible that some bad surveys have made it into Corva (like check shots for example).

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/11d6ad304cb3.png:Figure 2]

Once the DDA gets used to the color coding on the Hookload Broomstick apps it is possible to also quickly see if an activation was missed. Having pick up points that go to surface and 2 trend lines that don’t quite match in the slack off points would indicate that.
Circulating Pressure Loss app

The Circulating Pressure Loss Is included on the company dashboards for the same reason as the Hookload Broomstick app, the DDA is responsible for calibrating the model. The model will generate predicted standpipe pressure values for a given flow rate. The Predicted SPP, Actual SPP and Current Flowrate values are displayed on the app.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/3389f5218a2f.png:Figure 98]

If the DDA has calibrated the CPL model the predicted and actual values should be relatively close.  The histogram at the bottom of the app will display the divergence over time between the predicted and actual values. The app will make a new histogram bar about every 30 min and the value will be the average divergence over that period of time. If the CPL has been calibrated and the divergence suddenly changes the DDA should investigate what caused the change. If the change correlates to a data entry event (like a new mud report being entered), the DDA should recalibrate the model. If the change does not correlate to a data entry event the DDA should not change the calibration as this could mean that down hole conditions are changing (the hole could be packing off, or the motor could have failed).

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/339def288d73.png:Figure 5]

The pie chart in the middle of the CPL app is a representation of how much pressure is being lost in any portion of the path of flow. This is useful when initially calibrating the CPL model. If the DDA is having trouble calibrating the model this pie chart may help direct them to the correct area for troubleshooting.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/973c6c6976d7.png:Figure 105]

*Torque Broomstick app
*

The Torque Broomstick app is included in the company dashboard for a slightly less than intuitive reason. It will mainly be used to verify that the correct torque units are mapped to the torque mnemonic. Typically the issue with unit mapping is a difference in ft-lbf and ft-klbf. If all of the torque points are roughly 0 this could mean that the the values being sent are in ft-klbf and the units are mapped as ft-lbf. Conversely, if the torque points are plotting significantly higher than the torque model it could mean that the values are ft-lbf, but the mapped units are ft-klbf.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/13b84f9f4560.png:Figure 73]

*Directional Divergence app
*

The Directional Divergence app will display what well plan Corva has loaded, the last survey, the nearest well plan station, and the divergence. Most of the time surveys will be pulled automatically, so as long as the correct well plan is entered the DDA will not have many options for troubleshooting high directional divergence. The first step to troubleshooting divergence would be to bottom line the surveys and well plan to make sure that the data in Corva matches the files being sent. If those are good the DDA should look for a PVA report in the inbox to see if the divergence in Corva matches what the DD has. If the divergence does not match the DDA may need to request a new well plan.

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/13b84f9f4560.png:Figure 101]

*MSE vs Depth app
*

The MSE vs Depth app displays the MSE value that Corva calculates, the gamma ray, and the ROP. This app can be used as a quick method to see that the Gamma mapping and ROP mapping is correct. This is also a quick way to see that the MSE is being calculated. Basically if all 3 lines are being plotted and do not have long intervals of straight horizontal lines then

[IMAGE:/training-assets/1uqwWg1IUqPjbePmSUBjl0ZLfWNqwfj9ndRy4aTMlR_0/a8586de92a67.png:Figure 68]

quiz.question: A customer reports unexpected results in a Company Dashboards application. What should you check first?

options.text: Verify the input data quality and app configuration settings
Assume the app has a bug

quiz.explanation: App outputs depend on input data - always verify data quality before assuming app issues.
